title: 114_hr2992
content: The Act may be cited as the "Merchant Marine of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act". The Congress acknowledges the vital role of the United States Merchant Marine in World War II, providing essential supplies to the fighting forces overseas. Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King and President Dwight D. Eisenhower both recognized the Merchant Marine's crucial contribution to the Allied victory. The American Merchant Marine played a crucial role in delivering supplies and equipment to armed forces overseas and providing economic and military aid to friendly nations, strengthening the forces of freedom worldwide. Despite facing enemy combatants, the Merchant Marine ensured efficient and reliable transport of resources and personnel for military missions and war planning. The United States Merchant Marine played a vital role in World War II, facing enemy threats like bombers, submarines, and mines. They had a high casualty rate but were crucial in various operations, including supplying materials for the Normandy invasion. General Eisenhower praised their performance. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine played a crucial role, delivering goods in dangerous operations across oceans. President Roosevelt and General Eisenhower praised their loyalty, courage, and efficiency, deserving broader recognition. The US will always be grateful for their service. The United States Merchant Marine played a crucial role in World War II by transporting goods in enemy territory, saving lives, and contributing to the Allied Powers' victory. The Congressional Gold Medal will honor their service and highlight their instrumental role in winning the war. The Congressional Gold Medal will honor the United States Merchant Marine's crucial role in World War II. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for a gold medal to be awarded to the U.S. Merchant Marine of World War II. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal, and it will be given to the American Merchant Marine Museum for display and research. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze under regulations, covering costs. Medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under the Act.
